CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The polymer exhibits excellent stability with an onset decomposition temperature ( 1% weight loss ) at 280 °C in air. This level of thermal stability is adequate for applications in PSCs and other optoelectronic devices. Optical Properties. The absorption spectrum of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in film is shown in Figure 2 together with that of P3HT and normalized AM 1.5G photon flux for comparison. The polymer has a broad absorption band in the range of 500-1100 nm with a tail extending to 1.3 μm. The full width at half - maximum ( fwhm ) of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film is 324 nm , which is nearly a double that of P3HT film ( 158 nm ). The optical band gap of the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film is 1.13 eV , as estimated from the absorption onset ( 1100 nm ). All these data indicate that PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) can utilize a larger fraction of solar light that P3HT as a possible material for applications in micrometer response photovoltaic devices. Electrochemical Properties. Electrochemical cyclic voltammetry ( CV ) was performed to determine the highest occupied molecular orbital ( HOMO ) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) energy levels of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu ). The CV curves were recorded referenced to an Ag / Ag þ electrode , which was calibrated against the ferroceneferrocenium ( Fc / Fc þ ) redox couple ( 4.8 eV below the vacuum level ) ; the CV curves are shown in Figure 3. On the basis of the onset values of oxidation ( 0.10 V ) and reduction potential ( -1.17 V ) of the polymer , the HOMO and LUMO levels of the polymer were calculated as -4.90 and -3.63 eV , respectively. The electrochemical band gap thus determined is about 1.27 eV , which is slightly higher than the optical band gap. X-ray Diffraction ( XRD ) Measurements. The XRD patterns of the bulk samples of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PDTP - DTDPP(EH) were recorded to understand their structures in the solid state. As shown in Figure 4 , both samples show diffraction peaks at low angles , which could be attributed to a lamellar structure. The d-spacings of the diffraction from ( 100 ) are 14.8 and 14.9 Å for PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PDTP - DTDPP(EH) , respectively. The peaks around 24 ° for both polymers can be assigned to the face - to - face distance of the aromatic groups in the polymer chains arranged in the parallel direction. This π-π stacking distance of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) was 3.64 Å , slightly lower than that of PDTP - DTDPP(EH) ( 3.74 Å ) , which suggests that the butyl group in DPP segment is better for the close π-π stacking of the polymer backbones compared to the bulkier 2-ethylhexyl group. Hole Mobility. It has been strongly suggested that high hole mobility is an important requirement for effective photovoltaic polymers.

Let's think step by step.

1. "polymer" - a material that exhibits excellent stability and has thermal stability adequate for applications in PSCs and other optoelectronic devices.
2. "PDTP - DTDPP(Bu)" - a specific type of polymer with a broad absorption band and a tail extending to 1.3 μm.
3. "P3HT" - a material (polymer) used for comparison with PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in terms of absorption spectrum.
4. "AM 1.5G photon flux" - a standard reference spectrum used for comparison in the absorption spectrum.
5. "PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film" - a material (polymer film) with a full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of 324 nm.
6. "PDTP - DTDPP(EH)" - a specific type of polymer with a π-π stacking distance of 3.74 Å.
7. "Ag / Ag þ electrode" - a material used as a reference electrode in electrochemical cyclic voltammetry.
8. "ferroceneferrocenium ( Fc / Fc þ ) redox couple" - a material used as a reference in electrochemical cyclic voltammetry to calibrate the Ag / Ag þ electrode.
9. "PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu)" - a specific type of polymer with HOMO and LUMO energy levels calculated using electrochemical cyclic voltammetry.
10. "XRD patterns" - a material (patterns) recorded to understand the structures of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PDTP - DTDPP(EH) in the solid state.
11. "2-ethylhexyl group" - a material attached to the polymer chain in PDTP - DTDPP(EH) that affects the π-π stacking distance.
12. "butyl group in DPP segment" - a material attached to the polymer chain in PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) that affects the π-π stacking distance.
13. "high hole mobility" - a desirable material property for effective photovoltaic polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. "polymer"
2. "PDTP - DTDPP(Bu)"
3. "P3HT"
4. "PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film"
5. "PDTP - DTDPP(EH)"
6. "PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu)"
7. "XRD patterns"
8. "2-ethylhexyl group"
9. "butyl group in DPP segment"
10. "high hole mobility"

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| polymer |
| PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) |
| P3HT |
| PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film |
| PDTP - DTDPP(EH) |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| XRD patterns |
| 2-ethylhexyl group |
| butyl group in DPP segment |
| high hole mobility |

Paragraph: The polymer exhibits excellent stability with an onset decomposition temperature ( 1% weight loss ) at 280 °C in air. This level of thermal stability is adequate for applications in PSCs and other optoelectronic devices. Optical Properties. The absorption spectrum of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in film is shown in Figure 2 together with that of P3HT and normalized AM 1.5G photon flux for comparison. The polymer has a broad absorption band in the range of 500-1100 nm with a tail extending to 1.3 μm. The full width at half - maximum ( fwhm ) of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film is 324 nm , which is nearly a double that of P3HT film ( 158 nm ). The optical band gap of the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) film is 1.13 eV , as estimated from the absorption onset ( 1100 nm ). All these data indicate that PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) can utilize a larger fraction of solar light that P3HT as a possible material for applications in micrometer response photovoltaic devices. Electrochemical Properties. Electrochemical cyclic voltammetry ( CV ) was performed to determine the highest occupied molecular orbital ( HOMO ) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) energy levels of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu ). The CV curves were recorded referenced to an Ag / Ag þ electrode , which was calibrated against the ferroceneferrocenium ( Fc / Fc þ ) redox couple ( 4.8 eV below the vacuum level ) ; the CV curves are shown in Figure 3. On the basis of the onset values of oxidation ( 0.10 V ) and reduction potential ( -1.17 V ) of the polymer , the HOMO and LUMO levels of the polymer were calculated as -4.90 and -3.63 eV , respectively. The electrochemical band gap thus determined is about 1.27 eV , which is slightly higher than the optical band gap. X-ray Diffraction ( XRD ) Measurements. The XRD patterns of the bulk samples of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PDTP - DTDPP(EH) were recorded to understand their structures in the solid state. As shown in Figure 4 , both samples show diffraction peaks at low angles , which could be attributed to a lamellar structure. The d-spacings of the diffraction from ( 100 ) are 14.8 and 14.9 Å for PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PDTP - DTDPP(EH) , respectively. The peaks around 24 ° for both polymers can be assigned to the face - to - face distance of the aromatic groups in the polymer chains arranged in the parallel direction. This π-π stacking distance of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) was 3.64 Å , slightly lower than that of PDTP - DTDPP(EH) ( 3.74 Å ) , which suggests that the butyl group in DPP segment is better for the close π-π stacking of the polymer backbones compared to the bulkier 2-ethylhexyl group. Hole Mobility. It has been strongly suggested that high hole mobility is an important requirement for effective photovoltaic polymers.

Let's think step by step.

1. Thermal Stability: onset decomposition temperature, weight loss
2. Optical Properties: absorption spectrum, absorption band, full width at half-maximum (fwhm), optical band gap, photon flux
3. Electrochemical Properties: highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy level, lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level, electrochemical band gap, oxidation potential, reduction potential, calibration electrode
4. X-ray Diffraction (XRD) Measurements: diffraction peaks, d-spacings, lamellar structure, face-to-face distance of aromatic groups, π-π stacking distance
5. Hole Mobility: hole mobility.
